prompt: Discuss the role of working memory in complex cognition, evaluating models (e.g., Baddeley-Hitch) and links to reasoning, language, and learning.

criteria.name: Model Understanding
criteria.description: Explains key working memory models and components.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Accurately details phonological loop, visuospatial sketchpad, central executive, episodic buffer, and alternative models (e.g., embedded-processes).
performance_descriptors.good: Covers main components with minor omissions.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Partial or confused treatment of models.

criteria.name: Evidence and Tasks
criteria.description: Links models to tasks and empirical findings.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Connects components to tasks (digit span, complex span, n-back), neural correlates, and individual differences.
performance_descriptors.good: Provides relevant tasks with some evidence.

criteria.name: Applications to Cognition and Learning
criteria.description: Explains how working memory supports reasoning, language, and learning.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Provides nuanced links to reading comprehension, math problem solving, language processing, and instructional design implications.

criteria.name: Limitations and Critiques
criteria.description: Critically evaluates models and training claims.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Addresses limits of domain-general claims, transfer effects in training, and measurement challenges.
performance_descriptors.good: Notes several critiques with some analysis.

key_points: Describe Baddeley-Hitch model and alternatives with diagrams if allowed.
Link tasks like complex span and n-back to specific components.
Discuss individual differences and academic performance correlations.
Evaluate limits of WM training and near vs. far transfer.
Offer instructional design implications (e.g., cognitive load).
llm_questions: Explain the components of the Baddeley-Hitch model with examples.
What is the evidence for n-back training transfer effects?
How does working memory capacity relate to reading comprehension?
Design a classroom activity that reduces cognitive load.
Compare complex span and simple span tasks.
